Articles.Content:
KSP 1.0 has brought a lot of changes, both to aerodynamics and the specifications of many parts. The requirements for a successful launch to orbit have changed, so let's find out what makes the best lifters with the new version. **The Challenge:** Build and fly the most mass-efficient lifter possible to low Kerbin orbit. **The Rules** - Stock parts only. KSP version **1.0.5** only, entries from earlier versions will not be considered. Make sure you have [1.0.5.1028](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/developerarticles.html/ksp-105-is-live-r179/). - No cfg editing, save editing, debug menu, or any other shenanigans. - No physics exploits, the vessel must be lifted by thrust and aerodynamic lift alone. Decoupler force is permitted between propulsive stages, multiple stacked decouplers are not. - Payload must be mounted to a decoupler or docking node and separated from the lifter in a stable orbit with a periapsis of at least 70km. The decoupler/docking port must stay with the lifter. - Payload must be inert and contribute nothing but incidental body lift and command authority to the lifter (one crewed pod or probe core is ok, its reaction wheel and battery may be used but not its monopropellant, if any). All additional reaction wheels, batteries and fuel tanks in the payload must be disabled via tweakables. - **New:** Entries must be a single launch, with no interaction with any other vessels already in flight or launched afterward. - **New:** Parts placed on the bottom nodes of engines may not be moved using the offset tool. - The base of the lifter must be close to the pad surface, preferably touching it. No kilometer-high launch clamps please. - Please keep part clipping to a minimum. In particular, do not clip engines at all. - Please do not make a cargo bay the root part of your craft, to avoid a glitch/exploit discovered by Nao [here](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/116729-Stock-Payload-Fraction-Challenge-1-0-4-Edition?p=2042104&viewfull=1#post2042104). - Images or video of your design is required for entry, showing launch mass, payload mass in stable orbit, and enough in between to show how your vessel works. Craft files are encouraged so we can learn from each other's techniques. Permitted mods: Visual/immersion mods, informational mods, autopilot if that's your thing. This is primarily a design challenge. Forbidden mods: Anything that modifies stock parts, adds new parts, or changes the game's physics in any way. Aside from that, be creative. Build big or small, use exotic staging, mix and match propulsion types, whatever makes it more efficient. **The Scoring:** Score is a percentage, computed as PayloadMassInOrbit / TotalLaunchMass \* 100. Higher is better, and round to two decimal places. There are now four categories: *Unlimited* - Use any type of propulsion to get to orbit, no recovery necessary. *Unlimited Recoverable* - Use any type of propulsion to get to orbit, all non-payload parts must be safely recovered. *Rocket Only* - Rocket engines only (no ions, jets, or Rapiers in open cycle mode), no recovery necessary. *Rocket Recoverable* - Rocket engines only (no ions, jets, or Rapiers in open cycle mode), all non-payload parts must be safely recovered. **The Leaderboard:** Now for version 1.0.5: 1.0.5 Leaderboard | Unlimited | Recoverable Unlimited | Rocket Only | Recoverable Rocket | | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | |

Made a simple lifter that put 80.53 tonnes in orbit with 416.1 tonnes on the pad and generous remaining fuel. 19.35% payload efficiency.

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/7Q1Gn)

I believe this is the first entry, unless I've been sniped. No doubt somebody can probably do far better with either a spaceplane, nuclear launch vehicle, stratospheric ion-plane stage, asparagus-staging, tighter fuel margins, better flight profile, or a craft that isn't basically made by trial and error with no informational mods or fancy mathematics.

EDIT: First image replaced with correct payload after orbital insertion showing mass at 80.53 tonnes.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-04-29T10:20:54Z" title="04/29/2015 10:20  AM" data-short="9 yr">April 29, 2015</time> by Overfloater**

> Is this for single stage lifters? or are multistage designs allowed?

No restrictions on staging. Feel free to enter a single stage design, I'll note it's an SSTO on the leaderboard and split those off if there's enough of them.

Pds314 and Overfloater, thank you for your entries, I've updated the leaderboard. Those are excellent payload fractions for serially staged designs, under the old aero system such payload fractions would have required more exotic staging. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
Right, off to make some multistage lifters
Hey! Cool! Are jets allowed?

> 
> Hey! Cool! Are jets allowed?

Absolutely, all stock parts are allowed. If there are enough entries and jets start to dominate I'll split them off into a separate leaderboard, for now I'm keeping them together and noting which entry uses what.

Asparagus is not dead:

![p24pAaR.png](http://i.imgur.com/p24pAaR.png)

![ibyM5ks.png](http://i.imgur.com/ibyM5ks.png)

![Gay1wLR.png](http://i.imgur.com/Gay1wLR.png)

![xSPAdhE.png](http://i.imgur.com/xSPAdhE.png)

19.66%

Lost efficiency by:

Huge asparagus tanks on the side.

3.5m to 2.5m adapter that receives (much) more drag than it should (new aero issue).

Fairings being ejected.

Not orbiting perfectly at 70km.

I could fix that, but I am satisfied with the results.

Fix2: Removed clamps when measuring total rocket mass, and measuring it on the map screen.

Rocket mass: 251.51 tons

Payload mass: 50.71 tons

Final efficiency: 20.16%

These two above entries are disqualified by the above rule since with the new aero, the payloads add lift, i.e. they are lifting bodies. You should make a note that the payload must be enclosed in stock fairings.

Excellent challenge: to the point, simple and solid rules.

Will try after office hours. And wife hours. Sleep hours, what's that?

> 
> These two above entries are disqualified by the above rule since with the new aero, the payloads add lift, i.e. they are lifting bodies. You should make a note that the payload must be enclosed in stock fairings.

I think I'd rather just revise that rule to permit incidental body lift, rather than invalidate entries that followed the spirit of the rules I intended. Thanks for pointing that out, I'll update the rules.

> 
> Excellent challenge: to the point, simple and solid rules.
> Will try after office hours. And wife hours. Sleep hours, what's that?

Great, looking forward to your entry!

With my pure rocket (ie. not air breathing) I've achieved 22.52% ([link](https://youtu.be/cpvCr-9wQ2w)). I left the decoupler attached to the payload because it wasn't specified that I couldn't even though I think it's not quite kosher because it's usually not part of the payload.
Nicely done, SanderB! I think I'll specify that the decoupler should remain with the lifter, but I will still accept your entry.

Ok sure, maybe Ive clipped the tanks a bit. This is a 0.9 craft I havent even touched since. Started with 4260t craft, ended up with 863t of fuel left. Thats 20.2% fraction just in fuel. If you add the fraction for lightest tanks, this becomes 23%. 

Curiously Ive only used 3230 ms of delta V.... Some say it can be done with even less.
